content: Was able to solve it in python3. The use of both interestingness and strength as the comparison criteria is a bit confusing, but everything else works well. As others have suggested, could work fine for a duel, and more interesting problems is always a plus.

Ok for me. I don't really see the difficulty (it could be a clash) but it seams to be fun anyway. It would be nice to be able to give the URL of the other puzzles of the same theme, but it's a problem for CG, not you.
Changed Speed to Velocity anyway. Because as easy as it ends up, there's really no need to get it mixed up with Strength.
this puzzle looks like a one-liner for Ruby - shouldn't it be a clash then?

Write a program which, using a given number of strengths, identifies the two closest strengths and shows their difference with an integer.
it's very unclear, fix it - now it looks like u need to ignore their elegances and compare only speeds
u'd better describe the problem as finding the most interesting race's interest
As it says on the tin, this is the first evolution on top of Horse-racing Duals. Validation sets are sized to be brute-forceable (in bash, obviously ;-).

Thank you for your feedback.

The thing to keep in mind here is that this is a successor to the "Horse-racing duals" training puzzle. The wording is directly taken from there, be it for the target "Write a program that blah" or the name of the Strength property.
So I respectfully suggest you take your complaints about wording there.

Now about your complaint of unclearness, it looks like you're conflating speed and strength. (Correct me if I'm wrong?)

I agree it's unfortunate they share a starting letter, but it's hard to think of another pair of properties that remains meaningful in the context of a horse race. Would replacing "Speed" with "Velocity" help?

Feel free to constructively suggest actual sentences you'd consider more clear. "Fix it" category of injunctions are of no help at all, please keep those to yourself, thank you.

It could be, but then the progression (training easy puzzle -> this one -> the hard one) wouldn't make sense.
We could consider it once both others are out of the way.

The more general problem is: not everybody clashes.

Thanks for trying it out!

The difficulty is in the latent "do it in bash" challenge ;)
But same as links within statement text, it's not supported by the platform yet. (IMHO links would be a tricky feature anyway, there's a lot of potential for abuse)

(could be a clash, but it's harder than the original horse-racing duals which isn't) (and I don't clash anymore anyway) (I suppose I could resubmit one as a clash if there's demand from the clashers)

Oh, that's a good point!
I'll think it around.

I've updated the statement to remove the word "interestingness", and fit it better as an independent problem rather than one you have to solve with the original still fresh in your mind.

And I like the wording a lot better now. Thanks again!

(oh, and there are (alas) quite a few languages for which it isn't)

The "joke" part of this submission, which might be lost on many, is that the author-provided solution is in bash.
To be put in relation with the training puzzle's special achievement.
i mean just describe the problem as finding the most interesting race's interest - it'll be very clear and easy
I will as soon as the training puzzle does.
u don't need to copy original puzzle's description word-by-word

If I didn't copy the original, I wouldn't make it about horses (let alone Casablanca) and risk confusion between strength and speed.

So, no, sorry, this is not a free-form puzzle, it's got a few (unfortunate) constraints that it really has to follow for it to make any sense in the grand scheme of CG puzzles.

If it were a clash, I'd drop the theming altogether, just ask for the closest norm-1 pair distance in a single sentence.

But it's not.
(and, BTW, you're really way too high-level to be in the target audience for this. I'd value your opinion a lot more in one of my harder puzzles, say brackets ultimate)
